Yes, there are some exemptions and waivers available for the English proficiency and history/government knowledge tests. 

Exemptions for the English proficiency test are available for applicants who are:

- Age 50 or older and have held a green card for at least 20 years
- Age 55 or older and have held a green card for at least 15 years

If an applicant is granted an exemption, they will still need to take the history and government knowledge test but can do so in their native language.

For the history and government knowledge test, there may be accommodations available for applicants with disabilities. Applicants may request accommodations such as extra time, a sign language interpreter, or an oral interpreter if they have a physical or developmental disability that prevents them from taking the test in the usual manner. 

If an applicant is unable to read or write because of an age-related disability, they may be eligible for a waiver of the history and government knowledge test. However, they must still take the English proficiency test, unless they meet the exemptions mentioned above. 

To request accommodations or a waiver, the applicant must fill out the appropriate forms and provide medical documentation or other evidence to support their claim.
